title: Mr. McKee falls asleep. Tom breaks Myrtle's nose after she mentions Daisy's name.
text:
f the
old alignment gave a blurred air to her face. When she moved about
there was an incessant clicking as innumerable pottery bracelets
jingled up and down upon her arms. She came in with such a proprietary
haste, and looked around so possessively at the furniture that I
wondered if she lived here. But when I asked her she laughed
immoderately, repeated my question aloud, and told me she lived with a
girl friend at a hotel.

Mr. McKee was a pale, feminine man from the flat below. He had just
shaved, for there was a white spot of lather on his cheekbone, and he

relations.explanation: The narrator states 'I first met Tom Buchanan’s mistress'.
The text mentions 'Tom Buchanan’s mistress'.
The narrator describes Tom taking hold of his elbow and literally forcing him from the car, indicating a forceful interaction.
The narrator says 'I followed him', indicating he is accompanying Tom.
The narrator says 'George B. Wilson....and I followed Tom inside.'
Tom slaps Wilson jovially on the shoulder and discusses business.
Wilson wants to buy a car from Tom and asks 'When are you going to sell me that car?'
Tom responds coldly to Wilson's comment about the car, saying 'maybe I’d better sell it somewhere else after all.'
Myrtle shakes hands with Tom, looking him flush in the eye.
Myrtle walks 'through her husband as if he were a ghost'. She also speaks to him in a 'soft, coarse voice'.
Tom exchanges a frown with Doctor Eckleburg showing a negative sentiment.
Tom refers to Wilson as 'dumb he doesn’t know he’s alive' showing a clear disrespect.
Mrs. Wilson asks the dog seller about the puppies, showing an interest in buying one: 'What kind are they?' asked Mrs. Wilson eagerly, as he came to the taxi-window.
Mrs. Wilson says 'I think it’s cute' enthusiastically when referring to the dog.
The text describes Mrs. Wilson fondling the weatherproof coat with rapture after purchasing the dog.
Tom interposes and urges the narrator to come to the apartment, showing an insistence on the narrator's presence.
Myrtle urges the narrator to come to the apartment and says she will telephone her sister Catherine.
Myrtle says 'I’ll telephone my sister Catherine'.
Myrtle announces 'I’m going to have the McKees come up'.
Myrtle announces 'I’m going to have the McKees come up'.
The elevator boy went for items for the dog.
The narrator mentions 'Mrs. Wilson and I called each other by our first names'.
The sister, Catherine, was a slender, worldly girl of about thirty...company commenced to arrive at the apartment door.
Catherine tells the narrator she lives with a girl friend at a hotel.
The text states 'Mr. McKee was a pale, feminine man from the flat below'.
